Dr. R. B. Roulston, chairman of the
Language group, stated that his
department would not issue any
fixed and definite reading requirement.
Under the New Plan, requisites
of which were recently announced, the upper classmen are
required to have a general knowledge of the group in which they
are studying. It is not necessary,
however, to take courses to obtain this general knowledge.
The survey of an entire group
may be made by _reading the
books in the following lists.
Broad Knowledge Required
"Students majoring in any
branch of natural sciences are
required to have a broader
knowledge of the whole field of

_

special courses, which have been
followed as requirements for the
baccalaureate degree," it was
stated by Dr. Whyburn, associate
in mathematics. The students
will be expected to demonstrate
this by passing a comprehensive
examination toward the end of
their senior year.
"Such
broader
knowledge
should include," he continued,
"a general survey of the historical development of scientific
thought, an understanding of
the methods employed, the different branches recognized and
their interrelations, the major
conclusions on which they are
based and the lines of investigation now most actively pursued .
This will not be covered in formal
courses, but the students will be
expected to acquire as much as
possible from their own reading."
"The following books are advised
as those which contain the desired
knowledge in its best form :
Astronomy-Russell, Dugan, and
Stewart, Astronomy; J . H . Jeans,

Smith, History of Mathematics,

of Chemistry; Thorpe, Essays in

Pampered and martyred heroines, who have been suffering and
suffering gracefully in the tradition of the modern drama, have no
champion in Mrs. Diana Rogge,
Baltimore
playwright.
Mrs.
Rogge, who has just added to past
accomplishments the distinction
of winning the nation-\vide playwriting contest sponsored by the
Johns Hopkins University Playshop, said today that she has
eschewed older traditions in
"Modern Medley," the successful
play, and has started some of her
'own.
Satire On Modern Woman

In the play, a full length one,
Mrs. Rogge has penned a satire
on a modern woman who has
abandoned her husband and child
to attend bridge parties and psychology lectures. And then Mrs.
Rogge relates how the husband
feels about the whole business.
The setting of the satire is laid in
Greenwich, Connecticut, the congregating place, she .explained, of
all of the artists and bohemians
that tourists imagine are the
strang·e people they see in Green-

wich Village, New York.

KEITH"S: Charley Chase, stage

came interested in play writing
after she had composed a number of stories and verses for children. For some time, she related,
her manuscripts "bounced back"
as often as she mailed them to
publishers. But eventually they
stopped bouncing and some of
them were produced by theatrical
groups in Baltimore and other
cities. Several of the authoress's
plays that were produced in the
city are "Be Your Age," "See
Saw,'' and "Let's Be Human,'' the
last being one of the skits presented in the recent edition of the
Charles Street Follies.
Early Ambition Realized
Mrs. Rogge, a native of West
Virginia, moved to Baltimore
with her parents in her early
childhood. After graduating from
a local high school, she attended
a finishing . school in Roanoke,
Virginia. The authoress declared
that she has always been anxious
to write plays about the "smart
set"' and spir~tualists. Since the
former ambition has been realized
in "Modern Medley," she plans
to assemble information for a
f
sketch on mediums at some uture elate.
The playwright and her husband, Joseph Rogge, an accountant, live in the 200 block of \i\T.
:Madison St.
The winning play was selected
from over eighty manuscripts
submitted by authors residing in
